title: Closet Redo: Replacing Wire Shelving With Ikea Pax System
description: Transforming a walk in closet with wire shelving to built in IKEA Pax units.Â  Step-by-step guide for removing wire closet shelves and replacing them with the Pax closet system.Â  This is the second closet in our home I've made over with these Ikea units. My closet was first -- I went from this mess:Â  To this organized space that I enjoy everyday!:Â  The best part of building a custom Pax system for your specific closet needs is that it's SO much easier to keep clean. I rarely have things laying around anymore, because everything has a place.Â  I made some minor changes to my closet earlier this year that I'll share with you soon! This time I want to share the transformation of our teenage son's closet. I spared you the true before images. Let's just say it was a mess -- this is an area that had hardly been touched since we moved in nearly eight years ago! 1. Configure your closet specs I so wish we would have worked on this space earlier -- no better time to tackle this than a few months before he moves out for college, right?? ðŸ˜‚ We were both fed up with the mess, so we finally went after it a couple of months ago.Â  He'll be able to enjoy it all summer and on holiday breaks at least! :)Â  The first step in this process was to clean everything out from top to bottom:Â Read the full postThis content is property of Thrifty Decor Chick LLC. If you are reading this on any other site other than www.thriftydecorchick.com or one of the blog's social media platforms, please contact TDC immediately (thriftydecorchick at gmail dot com). Any other use of this content is strictly forbidden.
author: Thrifty Decor Chick
excerpt: Transforming a walk in closet with wire shelving to built in IKEA Pax units. Step-by-step guide for removing wire closet shelves ...
text: Transforming a walk in closet with wire shelving to built in IKEA Pax units.Â  Step-by-step guide for removing wire closet shelves and replacing them with the Pax closet system.Â  This is the second closet in our home I've made over with these Ikea units. My closet was first -- I went from this mess:Â  The best part of building a custom Pax system for your specific closet needs is that it's SO much easier to keep clean. I rarely have things laying around anymore, because everything has a place.Â  I made some minor changes to my closet earlier this year that I'll share with you soon! This time I want to share the transformation of our teenage son's closet. I spared you the true before images. Let's just say it was a mess -- this is an area that had hardly been touched since we moved in nearly eight years ago! 1. Configure your closet specs I so wish we would have worked on this space earlier -- no better time to tackle this than a few months before he moves out for college, right?? ðŸ˜‚ We were both fed up with the mess, so we finally went after it a couple of months ago.Â  He'll be able to enjoy it all summer and on holiday breaks at least! :)Â  The first step in this process was to clean everything out from top to bottom:Â  Actually, the very first thing we did was go through ALL of his clothes in both the dresser and this closet.Â  That was important to determine what kind/how much storage he would need in the new and improved closet.Â  Ikea offers a great online closet Pax planner tool. You can input the size of the room and then configure your units and any extra options:Â  This post may containÂ affiliate links for yourÂ convenience. I may earn a small commission whenÂ you make a purchase through links.Â  This is a narrow closet, so I wanted to utilize the long wall on the left of the closet and leave the wall straight ahead open for a tall mirror.Â  Because the light switch for the closet is just to the left of the doorway, I went with a more shallow unit there for shoes and shelving, and then two full depth Pax units to the right that we used for built in drawers and hanging clothes.Â  Our ceiling height upstairs is eight feet, so I purchased the 79 inch units. After I started assembling the closet, I realized I could have gone with the taller versions. But more on that in a minute! 2. Remove the wire shelving The existing wire shelving is pretty easy to remove, you just need to know how to do it so you don't create more drywall damage than necessary.Â  I find a regular hammer is easiest for removing most of the parts:Â  You'll want to remove the shelf supports underneath the wire shelves first -- do so by grabbing the head of the pin with the claw end of the hammer and rocking it out of the wall.Â  Then you can let the wire shelving hang against the wall while removing the anchors:Â  Those anchors have two long prongs that are inside the drywall, but there's really no delicate way to remove them. You're going to have a significant hole left, so just pop those out with your hammer as well.Â  When you get going this process is very fast -- just make sure to remove the metal pin first because you'll make a much bigger hole in the wall if you try to remove with that inserted.Â  You'll be left when a bunch of holes in the wall, but here's my secret...I don't fill them if they'll be covered with the new Pax units. ðŸ˜³ My future self may regret it, but I don't see us taking down this closet system anytime soon.Â  3. Assemble and install the Pax wardrobe frames Ikea has changed the design of their Pax units since my first experience years ago. Before, you had an option to assemble the units on the floor (which I preferred) and then move them into place.Â  I did learn then that sometimes it's best to assemble them vertically, especially if you have any odd turns or angles that may make it hard to get the entire piece into the closet.Â  Now Ikea has made it so they are entirely assembled vertically, on the wall where they will be installed. I actually really liked it, but after the fact I realized I could have gone with the 93 inch version instead of the 79.Â  Not a huge deal really, as we ended up with plenty of storage space for his needs. But just keep that in mind -- even if you have eight foot ceilings, you can most likely take advantage of all of that vertical space now.Â  The instructions are fairly self-explanatory. There's a metal bracket that will need to be attached to the wall into studs or with significant anchors. You can see that bracket at the top of the unit here:Â  And then you add the bottom and top panels before adjusting your shelving or hanging rods:Â  4. Add the finishing touchesÂ  This is the fun part! The versatility of this Ikea Pax closet system is what I love so much about it. I enjoy figuring out the best way to store items with their built in drawers, pull out shelves and other options you can add to the unit. In the middle Pax unit of his closet, we were able to use the drawers I had first installed in my closet makeover: I removed those earlier this year to add pull out hanging pants storage to that spot, and kept them knowing we could use them in my son's closet:Â  This freed up so much space in his bedroom dresser! We used mostly regular shelves in the shallow Pax unit, but I did add two pull out Ikea shelves as well. One was for his accessories like ties and belts:Â  He keeps most of his shoes in our mud room shoe storage, but I added a pull out drawer at the bottom of these shelves for his dress shoes.Â  These make it easy to grab things like belts, jewelry, etc. I use the one in my closet nearly every day:Â  5. Decorate and accessorize (yes, even in a closet!) I mean...don't go crazy. But if it's a walk in closet, you're probably in there a good amount of time! Why not make it a space you enjoy?Â  I'm a bit of a freak and find wallpapering the wallsÂ takes less time than painting numerous coats of paint. All the prep -- cutting in, taping off and all that jazz -- takes a lot of time.Â  I used the leftovers and picked up a couple more rolls to install on the closet walls: It's photographing a little lighter than the actual color here. Check out the photos below for a more realistic look.Â  I had bit of space left above the closet units and didn't want to buy another roll of wallpaper, so I got a small can of this Loyal Blue color from Sherwin-Williams to paint that area:Â  You can see that I taped a scrap of the wallpaper next to the color -- I could have gone with the more aqua accent above as well! Our son is a huge movie buff and had quite a few posters that didn't fit quite right anywhere else. We framed those and hung them on the long wall to the right of the door:Â  We weren't using that space anyway, so it turned out to a great spot to add a few things he loves! He has an overhead light, but these make it easy to grab something in the dark.Â  Overall the room looks completely different, but also functions SO MUCH BETTER:Â  Can you believe our 18-year-old has kept this entire closet pristine for more than a month now? I guess that shouldn't surprise me, as I've done the same with mine over the past few years as well. My husband's closet is next on the list! :) Â  Overall the whole closet makeover took about five days -- the first was removing the wire shelves and filling holes. The second and third were installing the Pax units and adjustable shelves.Â  The last couple of days were spent hanging the wallpaper, mirror and art, as well as touching up paint and cleaning up.Â  What a difference!:Â  I'm still a little annoyed I didn't go with the taller units, but overall it wouldn't have added anymore hanger space. The two stacked hanging sections on the end are a perfect fit.Â  All we would have gained is room for a few more shelves or drawers: Here's the before and after, that would be a lot more dramatic if I had included the before version with clothes all over the floor:Â  And how the room looks (all the time!) now:Â  If only we could have done this sooner!Â  This last semester of high school wore. me. out! Thankfully we are done with graduation, his grad party and even college orientation.Â  Now we relax all summer and soak in the time with our boy. ðŸ’™
html:
Transforming a walk in closet with wire shelving to built in IKEA Pax units.Â 

Step-by-step guide for removing wire closet shelves and replacing them with the Pax closet system.Â 

This is the second closet in our home I've made over with these Ikea units. My closet was first -- I went from this mess:Â 

The best part of building a custom Pax system for your specific closet needs is that it's SO much easier to keep clean. I rarely have things laying around anymore, because everything has a place.Â 

I made some minor changes to my closet earlier this year that I'll share with you soon!

This time I want to share the transformation of our teenage son's closet. I spared you the true before images. Let's just say it was a mess -- this is an area that had hardly been touched since we moved in nearly eight years ago!

1. Configure your closet specs

I so wish we would have worked on this space earlier -- no better time to tackle this than a few months before he moves out for college, right?? ðŸ˜‚ We were both fed up with the mess, so we finally went after it a couple of months ago.Â 

He'll be able to enjoy it all summer and on holiday breaks at least! :)Â 

The first step in this process was to clean everything out from top to bottom:Â 

Actually, the very first thing we did was go through ALL of his clothes in both the dresser and this closet.Â 

That was important to determine what kind/how much storage he would need in the new and improved closet.Â 

Ikea offers a great online closet Pax planner tool. You can input the size of the room and then configure your units and any extra options:Â 

This post may containÂ affiliate links for yourÂ convenience.

I may earn a small commission whenÂ you make a purchase through links.Â 

This is a narrow closet, so I wanted to utilize the long wall on the left of the closet and leave the wall straight ahead open for a tall mirror.Â 

Because the light switch for the closet is just to the left of the doorway, I went with a more shallow unit there for shoes and shelving, and then two full depth Pax units to the right that we used for built in drawers and hanging clothes.Â 

Our ceiling height upstairs is eight feet, so I purchased the 79 inch units. After I started assembling the closet, I realized I could have gone with the taller versions. But more on that in a minute!

2. Remove the wire shelving

The existing wire shelving is pretty easy to remove, you just need to know how to do it so you don't create more drywall damage than necessary.Â 

I find a regular hammer is easiest for removing most of the parts:Â 

You'll want to remove the shelf supports underneath the wire shelves first -- do so by grabbing the head of the pin with the claw end of the hammer and rocking it out of the wall.Â 

Then you can let the wire shelving hang against the wall while removing the anchors:Â 

Those anchors have two long prongs that are inside the drywall, but there's really no delicate way to remove them. You're going to have a significant hole left, so just pop those out with your hammer as well.Â 

When you get going this process is very fast -- just make sure to remove the metal pin first because you'll make a much bigger hole in the wall if you try to remove with that inserted.Â 

You'll be left when a bunch of holes in the wall, but here's my secret...I don't fill them if they'll be covered with the new Pax units. ðŸ˜³

My future self may regret it, but I don't see us taking down this closet system anytime soon.Â 

3. Assemble and install the Pax wardrobe frames

Ikea has changed the design of their Pax units since my first experience years ago. Before, you had an option to assemble the units on the floor (which I preferred) and then move them into place.Â 

I did learn then that sometimes it's best to assemble them vertically, especially if you have any odd turns or angles that may make it hard to get the entire piece into the closet.Â 

Now Ikea has made it so they are entirely assembled vertically, on the wall where they will be installed. I actually really liked it, but after the fact I realized I could have gone with the 93 inch version instead of the 79.Â 

Not a huge deal really, as we ended up with plenty of storage space for his needs. But just keep that in mind -- even if you have eight foot ceilings, you can most likely take advantage of all of that vertical space now.Â 

The instructions are fairly self-explanatory. There's a metal bracket that will need to be attached to the wall into studs or with significant anchors. You can see that bracket at the top of the unit here:Â 

And then you add the bottom and top panels before adjusting your shelving or hanging rods:Â 

4. Add the finishing touchesÂ 

This is the fun part! The versatility of this Ikea Pax closet system is what I love so much about it. I enjoy figuring out the best way to store items with their built in drawers, pull out shelves and other options you can add to the unit.

In the middle Pax unit of his closet, we were able to use the drawers I had first installed in my closet makeover:

I removed those earlier this year to add pull out hanging pants storage to that spot, and kept them knowing we could use them in my son's closet:Â 

This freed up so much space in his bedroom dresser!

We used mostly regular shelves in the shallow Pax unit, but I did add two pull out Ikea shelves as well. One was for his accessories like ties and belts:Â 

He keeps most of his shoes in our mud room shoe storage, but I added a pull out drawer at the bottom of these shelves for his dress shoes.Â 

These make it easy to grab things like belts, jewelry, etc. I use the one in my closet nearly every day:Â 

5. Decorate and accessorize (yes, even in a closet!)

I mean...don't go crazy. But if it's a walk in closet, you're probably in there a good amount of time! Why not make it a space you enjoy?Â 

I'm a bit of a freak and find wallpapering the wallsÂ takes less time than painting numerous coats of paint. All the prep -- cutting in, taping off and all that jazz -- takes a lot of time.Â 

I used the leftovers and picked up a couple more rolls to install on the closet walls:

It's photographing a little lighter than the actual color here. Check out the photos below for a more realistic look.Â 

I had bit of space left above the closet units and didn't want to buy another roll of wallpaper, so I got a small can of this Loyal Blue color from Sherwin-Williams to paint that area:Â 

You can see that I taped a scrap of the wallpaper next to the color -- I could have gone with the more aqua accent above as well!

Our son is a huge movie buff and had quite a few posters that didn't fit quite right anywhere else. We framed those and hung them on the long wall to the right of the door:Â 

We weren't using that space anyway, so it turned out to a great spot to add a few things he loves!

He has an overhead light, but these make it easy to grab something in the dark.Â 

Overall the room looks completely different, but also functions SO MUCH BETTER:Â 

Can you believe our 18-year-old has kept this entire closet pristine for more than a month now? I guess that shouldn't surprise me, as I've done the same with mine over the past few years as well.

My husband's closet is next on the list! :) Â 

Overall the whole closet makeover took about five days -- the first was removing the wire shelves and filling holes. The second and third were installing the Pax units and adjustable shelves.Â 

The last couple of days were spent hanging the wallpaper, mirror and art, as well as touching up paint and cleaning up.Â 

What a difference!:Â 

I'm still a little annoyed I didn't go with the taller units, but overall it wouldn't have added anymore hanger space. The two stacked hanging sections on the end are a perfect fit.Â 

All we would have gained is room for a few more shelves or drawers:

Here's the before and after, that would be a lot more dramatic if I had included the before version with clothes all over the floor:Â 

And how the room looks (all the time!) now:Â 

If only we could have done this sooner!Â 

This last semester of high school wore. me. out! Thankfully we are done with graduation, his grad party and even college orientation.Â 

Now we relax all summer and soak in the time with our boy. ðŸ’™
